description: NULL
NULL
NULL
NULL

• different configuration for L1Calo in eta region near crack at 1.45: previously L1Calo was sampling only from the Endcap while now it is sampling from the barrel in this difficult region. See explanation by Trigger Coordination for details.

• 158045, 158116 (LAr): HECC is YELLOW in the head tag, but GREEN in the analysis tag. There is an unmasked noisy channel (3/5/90) creating clusters at (eta,phi) = (-1.65;2.50), seen both by tau and Jet CP groups.

• 158466 (LAr): HECC, hot spot at eta=1.85, phi = 1.92 seen in both express and bulk processing due to FT 3 SL 6 CH 115.
  • 158545 (LAr): Hot spot in EMECC at eta=-1.75, phi = -1.132. "Misbehaving channel" tool identified it as in LB 256 only.
NULL
NULL
NULL
• 159224: 1 ROD disabled during the run (48 modules in the barrel). These modules are located at phi around 0.4 and positive eta in the barrel.

• run 160479 was taken after an improvement in the RPC timing was made. So, the muon trigger efficiency for this and the following runs will generally differ from that in previous runs.
  • TGC: for runs 160469 - 160472 a narrower timing gate was applied: 25 (25) ns for wire (strip) instead of the nominal 35 (45) ns. This can affect the muon efficiency in the TGC region. See also the Elog entry by Masaya.
• same as E1

• for the Tier0 reconstruction the *frozen* Tier0 policy was violated deliberately. The "TRT irreproducibility bug" was finally fixed. This will affect secondary tracks reconstructed by the backtracking algorithm and TRT standalone tracks. It does not affect prompt tracks reconstructed by the inside-out algorithm.
  • the egamma HLT triggers were changed to recover a previous inefficiency of ~10%: the calo shower shape cuts reta and weta2 were relaxed. For more info see Valerios talk

• the L2_mu6/10 trigger chains are now seeded by L1_MU0 to recover from the unexpectedly low L1_MU6/10 efficiency. For more info see Alex Ohs talk
  • TGC: for runs 160972-161118 a narrower timing gate was applied: 25 (25) ns for wire (strip) instead of the nominal 35 (45) ns. In addition the delay was changed by -5ns (+5ns) for the wires (strips). This can affect the muon efficiency in the TGC region. See also the Elog entry by Masaya.

• L1Calo trigger was reconfigured in the crack region to now include only the Endcap again as it was in periods A-C1.
  • TGC: see period E4 for run 161118. For runs 161379 and onwards the clock phase was adjusted by 4ns (see Elog entry by Masaya)
• no changes w.r.t. E5 (TGC clock settings as in run 161379)
• run 161948: TGC trigger-roads for L1_MU6 ... 20 increased, see this Elog entry. The efficiency should be improved by 4% compared to previously.

• starting with run 162526 the Pixel readout window was decreased from 3 to 2 BCs.
  • RPC: timing configuration was adjusted for runs >162526. The effect should be ~2% (see this Elog entry)
• same as F1
NULL

• RPC timing configuration reverted to the one before run 162526 (problems in readout window)
  • L1Calo: Tile drawer EBC42 calibration constants rolled back

• TGC went from 3-station to 2-station coincidence to recover 2-3% efficiency loss. Triggers seeded by L1_MU0 are unaffected, since it always had 2-station coincidence; triggers seeded by L1_MU6 or L1_MU10 are affected.

• Tile RAW data were not written and instead the online information was used for reconstruction. The exact consequences of this are still under study. For this period the Tile reconstruction of out-of-time is biased. These data should not be used for analyses exploiting beta measurements based on Tile data.

• Tile raw data are again being written as usual.
  • during runs 165954, 165956 and 166142 ATLAS experienced a large beam-halo background. The BCM measured a rate of about 800 Hz. This caused operational problems. The DQ system and CP groups have so far judged the performance of the detector to be not affected strongly. Further work is ongoing to assess this statement. Please, report any issues you find with these runs.

• update to RPC timing
  • Pixel readout speed changed to 80 Mbit/s. Should have no impact on physics.
  • Use ATLAS-GEO-10-00-02 and COMCOND-BLK*-004-01 to fix minor cabling bug in the muon system.
  • run 168198: during the start of the run many events were written into the debug stream due to a trigger menu misconfiguration. The impact on physics has been estimated to be small (0.4%). The trigger DQ flags are thus set to green as the run is perfectly good for physics. All analyses are in any case strongly encouraged to run on the debug stream always.
  • run 168305-168383: 6 (out of 16) CSC sectors were not operational on the A-side.

• run 166850 was the run where a Van-der-Meer scan was done at the CMS, LHCb and ALICE experiments and ATLAS ran with a rather special trigger menu. The luminosity of this run is only 7.5 nb-1 and a large bandwidth was given to a special high-multiplicity trigger.
• new RPC timing calibration, see this elog entry

NULL
NULL
NULL
NULL
• readout problem in pixel B-layer in run 168875 (possible impact still being assessed for tracking and/or dE/dx measurement), set to GREEN in DetStatus-v03-pass1-analysis-2010J-Pixelloose tag
• same as J1 but more bunches (up to 113 bunches colliding in ATLAS)
• same as J2

• same as J2 and J3
  • data processing done at Tier1

• solenoid off
  • data processing done at Tier0

• solenoid back on
  • data processing done at Tier1
• data processing at Tier0
unsqueezed stable beam data (beta*=10m): typical beam spot width in x and y is 50-60 microns.
first squeezed stable beams (beta*=2m): typical beam spot width in x and y is 30-40 microns.
very similar to period B but higher luminosity due to more bunches in machine

<li> "nominal" LHC bunches (~0.9E11 p/bunch), beta*=3.5m
<li> pileup now significant: about 1.3 interactions per crossing (was < 0.15 before)
<li> z-vertex distribution about 50% longer than previously
<li> L1Calo configuration as in period C2

• different L1 Calo configuration near eta region of 1.45: it is now using just the presampler. See explanation by Trigger Coordination for details.
  • during the technical stop an improved RPC timing was installed.
  • *brand new trigger menu*: the previous data were taken with the *InitialBeams* menu while these data are now taken with the *Physics* menu. *This also affects the streams*: the main physics streams are now physics_JetTauEtmiss, physics_Egamma, physics_MinBias and physics_Muons. The streams called physics_L1Calo, physics_L1MinBias etc. now only contain data outside the stablebeams period and are generally not useful for physics analyses.
36 colliding bunches in ATLAS

<li> bunch trains with 150ns spacing from LHC
<li> CSC 6mm alignment fix
<li> muon HLT alignment fix (was unaligned before in HLT)
<li> definition of unpaired bunch group has changed
<li> L1Calo calibration update (minor effect on trigger expected)
<li> L2 jet HLT is activated, jetNoCut are migrated to jetNoEF

<li> 233 colliding bunches in ATLAS
<li> the CSC problem that affected the last two runs in periodG6 got fixed

<li> 295 colliding bunches in ATLAS
<li> the RPC window was unstretched in the L1 trigger, i.e. now only one BC contributes to L1 decisions

50ns data after the technical stop. The MDT's switched to "MROD trailer suppression mode" but this is not expected to impact physics. For Tier0 reconstruction improved conditions were applied to correct for the EMEC sagging and for the tilt of the ID w.r.t. the solenoid field.

new trigger cache which uses pileup noise suppression EMEC sagging correction. In particular jet and tau trigger threshold should be sharper w.r.t. the offline. SCT is now also in X1X readout mode (but this should not impact physics as the detector is well timed in).

update to L1 muon firmware to fix problem with misconfiguration affecting A-side only. The muon trigger efficiency is expected to be improved at eta=0.8-1.0 with respect to previous data periods.

Starting at H3 a b-jet trigger was fixed. See comment in H3.
data after the July technical stop: the 4 LAr FEBs in Layer2 are recovered!
